questions.text: A burns victim passes away 96 hours after sustaining burns. The probable cause of death is:
questions.solution:
Septic shock is the probable cause of death in this patient. 

In burns, the most common cause of

  • Death at the site of Burns - Asphyxia
  • Early death - Hypovolemic Shock
  • Late Death - Septicemia
  • Overall Deaths - Septicemia

questions.text: A female patient has dysphagia, with  intermittent epigastric pain. On endoscopy, the esophagus was found to be dilated above and narrow at the bottom. Treatment is _______
questions.solution:
The clinical picture points towards achalasia cardia, for which the treatment of choice is laparoscopic Heller myotomy.

Treatment of achalasia cardia:

Non-surgical:

  • Medications
    • Sublingual nitroglycerin, nitrates/calcium-channel blockers
  • Pneumatic dilatation
    • Disadvantage - Need for frequent multiple interventions
    • Risk of esophageal perforations
  • Botox injection
    • Symptoms may recur in 50% of the patients within 6 months

Surgical—Treatment of choice

  • Modified laparoscopic Heller myotomy is the operation of choice.
    • Advantage: Definite treatment of end-stage achalasia patient
    • Eliminates the risk of carcinoma in the resected area
    • Approaches - Transthoracic/Transhiatal
  • Esophagectomy is considered in any symptomatic patient with the following:
    • tortuous esophagus (megaesophagus)
    • sigmoid esophagus
    • failure of more than one myotomy
    • reflux stricture that is not amenable to dilation
  • Peroral endoscopic myotomy (POEM) is a recently introduced, advanced natural-orifice approach for myotomy.
    • The addition of a partial antireflux procedure, such as a Toupet or Dor fundoplication, will restore a barrier to the reflux and decrease the severity of postoperative symptoms.

questions.text:
A man is rushed to the ER after losing control of his car and crashing into a tree. Examination findings are given below. What is the most likely cause for his presentation?

BP - 190/100 mmHg

Respiratory rate - 22/minute

GCS - 9/15

Temperature - 106.8 °F

Head and neck examination - Minor abrasions over the face

CNS - Quadriparesis. Pupils are 2 mm and unreactive.
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of pontine haemorrhage. Clinical features of pontine haemorrhage are:

  • Deep coma
  • Quadriparesis and multiple cranial nerve dysfunction
  • Decerebrate rigidity
  • Pin-point pupils
  • Hyperpnea, hyperpyrexia, severe hypertension, and hyperhidrosis

Option A: The presence of hyperpyrexia and pin-point pupils rule out the possibility of spinal cord trauma.

Option B: Morphine poisoning is a differential diagnosis for pin-point pupils. But it leads to slower respiratory rate, not tachypnea.

Option D: In ponto-medullary laceration, medullary involvement would cause respiratory depression, leading to apnea. But here tachypnea is noted.

questions.text: A patient comes with complaints of abdominal pain associated with wrist drop. On examination there is blue color lines on gums. The patient works at glass painting company. Which of the following is the appropriate diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Lead poisoning is most commonly seen in people working in battery industries, rubber and news printing industries, acrylic painting, glass painting and pottery painting industries. Symptoms of lead toxicity include

Inorganic lead toxicity:

  • Abdominal colic
  • Obstipation
  • Constipation
  • Anemia
  • Wrist drop or foot drop

Organic lead toxicity:

  • Headache
  • Delirium
  • Insomnia

Earliest and consistent sign - Facial pallor.

Burtonian line-Blue line is seen on the gums in lead poisoning.

questions.text: A young donor came to the blood bank for the first time for platelet apheresis with platelet count of 1.9L. During the course he developed paresthesias and circumoral numbness during donation. His vitals remained stable though. ECG showed tachycardia with ST-T changes. What is the reason for his symptoms?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a young patient developing paresthesia and circumoral numbness and ECG showing ST-T changes during blood donation for platelet apheresis is consistent with hypocalcemia. 

Hypocalcemia in this case is due to citrate which is used as an anticoagulant in apheresis machine. Citrate is a calcium chelator and bind to the calcium in the donor’s circulation. 

During a physical examination, Chvostek's sign (twitching of the muscles around the mouth when the facial nerve is gently tapped) and Trousseau's sign (carpal spasm induced by inflating a blood pressure cuff to 20 mmHg above the patient's systolic blood pressure for 3 minutes) may be seen. Severe hypocalcemia can lead to various complications including seizures, spasms in the hands and feet (carpopedal spasm), bronchospasm, laryngospasm, and QT prolongation.

For acute and symptomatic hypocalcemia, the initial treatment involves intravenous administration of calcium gluconate, usually 10 mL of a 10% solution given over 5 minutes.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient who presented with a scrotal swelling underwent an orchidectomy. The image below shows the histopathology findings. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Based on the gross and microscopic appearance of the specimen, the diagnosis is seminoma.

The gross specimen shows a well-circumscribed, pale, gray-white, fleshy, homogenous mass, with a lobulated cut surface, usually devoid of hemorrhage or necrosis. Histopathology shows uniform tumor cells with abundant clear cytoplasm, distinct cell borders, and large central nuclei. There is a sparse lymphocytic infiltrate. Classically, they have a fried egg appearance.

Other options:

Option B: Yolk-sac tumor has a yellowish-white, mucinous appearance. Histologically, they are typically composed of a lace-like (reticular) network of medium-sized cuboidal, flattened, or spindled cells, which generally show less cytologic atypia than embryonal carcinoma. In approximately 50% of tumors, structures resembling endodermal sinuses (Schiller-Duval bodies) may be seen; these consist of a mesodermal core with a central capillary and a visceral and parietal layer of cells resembling primitive glomeruli. 

Option C: Embryonal cell carcinoma appears variegated with foci of hemorrhage or necrosis.  Histologically, the cells grow in alveolar or tubular patterns, sometimes with papillary folds. More undifferentiated lesions may display sheets of cells with cleft-like spaces. The neoplastic cells have an epithelial appearance, are large and anaplastic, and have hyperchromatic nuclei with prominent nucleoli. The cell borders are usually indistinct, and there is considerable variation in cell and nuclear size and shape (pleomorphism). Mitotic figures and tumor giant cells are frequently seen.

Option D: Teratomas also have a variegated appearance but have cysts reflecting the multiplicity of tissue types. Histologically, collections of differentiated cells or organoid structures originating in all 3 germ layers can be seen. Elements may be mature (resembling various adult tissues) or immature (sharing histologic features with fetal or embryonic tissue).

questions.text: A patient was sputum negative for tuberculosis, but chest X-ray was suggestive of tuberculosis. Which is the next step according to RNTCP ?
questions.solution:
• CB-NAAT and Line probe assay are rapid molecular diagnostic techniques used for diagnosis of tuberculosis and also to assess resistance to isoniazid and rifampicin.
  • CB NAAT (Cartridge Based Nucleic Acid Amplification Test) provides rapid and accurate diagnosis of TB by detecting Mycobacterium tuberculosis and mutations responsible for rifampicin resistance.
  • It can be used for sputum samples as well as samples from extrapulmonary sites.
  • It is mainly used for diagnosis of DR-TB in presumptive DR-TB patients and TB in key populations such as pediatric population, PLHIV and extrapulmonary TB.
  • It is done when smear is negative for TB but chest X-ray is suggestive of tuberculosis and also in cases smear is negative and chest X-ray is not suggestive of TB but there is high index of clinical suspicion. 

Diagnostic algorithm for pulmonary TB:

questions.text: The following image shows the retrograde ureteropyelogram of a patient with loin pain. What is the most probable clinical diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image showing dilated clubbed calyces with stricture of the left ureteropelvic junction points to a diagnosis of hydronephrosis.

Hydronephrosis refers to the dilatation of the pelvicalyceal system caused by a partial or complete blockage of urinary flow. 

Investigations:

  • Ultrasound is the least invasive technique for diagnosing hydronephrosis.
  • Retrograde pyelography is rarely indicated but will confirm the site of obstruction before corrective surgery.
  • Intravenous urogram (IVU) is helpful only if the obstructed kidney is functional. In IVU, the extrarenal pelvis is dilated and the minor calyces lose their normal cupping. In early stages, there is blunting of calyces followed by its clubbing in the late stages.
  • A renal isotope scan (DTPA or MAG-3) is the best modality to confirm the obstructive dilatation of the collecting system.

Related Pearl: Causes of Hydronephrosis

Unilateral hydronephrosis

Extramural obstruction

  • Tumor from adjacent structures, e.g., cervix, prostate, rectum, colon, or cecum
  • Retrocaval ureter
  • Aberrant renal vessels
  • Idiopathic retroperitoneal fibrosis (Ormond’s disease)

Intramural obstruction

  • Congenital PUJ obstruction - most common congenital cause
  • Congenital stenosis
  • Ureterocele
  • Ureteric stricture - iatrogenic/ inflammatory
  • Neoplasm of the ureter or bladder involving the ureteric orifice

Intraluminal obstruction

  • Renal stones - most common acquired unilateral cause
  • Sloughed papilla in papillary necrosis (especially, in patients with diabetes, analgesic abuse, or sickle cell disease)

Bilateral hydronephrosis

Congenital

  • Posterior urethral valves (associated with pulmonary hypoplasia)
  • Urethral atresia
  • PUJ obstruction

Acquired     

  • Benign prostatic hypertrophy or carcinoma of the prostate
  • Idiopathic retroperitoneal fibrosis (Ormond's disease)
  • Postoperative bladder neck scarring
  • Urethral stricture
  • Phimosis

Related Pearl: IVU signs and associated conditions

Medullary sponge kidney 

  • Bouquet of flowers/ paintbrush appearance
  • It refers to the cystic dilatation of the distal collecting tubules

Duplex kidney

  • Drooping lily sign
  • It refers to the inferolateral displacement of the lower pole due to an obstructed upper pole in a duplicated collecting system

Horseshoe kidney

  • Handshake sign - due to the position of the lower poles closer to the spine, and the lower calyces closer to each other
  • Flower vase sign - due to medially rotated calyces

Retroperitoneal fibrosis

  • Maiden waist deformity 
  • It refers to the medially drawn ureters caused by fibrosis at the lumbosacral junction

Retrocaval ureter 

  • Fish hook / Reverse J deformity 
  • Right ureter hooks behind the IVC as it passes posterior to it

Ureterocele

  • Cobra/ Adder head appearance
  • It refers to the dilation of the distal ureter

Transitional cell carcinoma of the ureter

  • Goblet sign
  • It is due to the focal dilation of the ureter by an intraluminal mass

questions.text: An adult whose both lower limbs are charred along with genitalia has ____ burns.
questions.solution:
Using Wallace’s Rule of 9, the % total burn surface area:

  • One lower limb =  Thigh (9%) + leg (9%) = 18%
  • Genitals = 1%

Hence, in this patient, one lower limb+ other lower limb + genital =  18% + 18% + 1% = 37%.

Related Pearl: Wallace's rule of 9

9%

R-UL

9%

R- thigh

9%

9%

L-thigh

9%

Anterior chest

9%

R- leg

9%

Upper back

9%

L- leg

9%

9%

Total

54%

  

46%

questions.text: A man met with a road traffic accident, which resulted in paralysis of both his upper and lower limbs. He has not passed urine and tenderness is elicited in the cervical region. What will you advise regarding radiography?

choices.text: The patient should not be shifted and portable x-ray machine should be used after neck stabilization.
Instruct the radiographer to take cervical and chest x-ray.
Instruct the radiographer to take cervical x-ray AP and lateral view without any cervical support.
Order a cervical x-ray and shift the patient from the trolley by himself.

questions.solution:
The given clinical situation suggests a cervical spine injury due to trauma. The patient should not be shifted and a portable X-ray machine should be used for radiography after neck stabilization.

Management in a trauma patient with a suspected cervical fracture involves the following steps:

  1. Spinal immobilization with a rigid cervical collar and a long spine board is the immediate step in the management of blunt/penetrating cervical trauma cases.
  2. It is followed by a gross assessment of spinal cord function by eliciting extremity movement. Tenderness over the injured vertebrae or the presence of a deformity is indicative of an associated fracture.
  3. Imaging is done by X-ray or CT. Portable X-ray machines are preferred to avoid further injury while mobilizing the patient. They are useful in visualizing thoracic and lumbar vertebrae but not the cervicothoracic junction. Cervical CT has been made the modality of choice in most emergency departments owing to the high quality of images that can be obtained.

questions.text: Identify the below condition which is present from birth:
questions.solution:
Congenital melanocytic nevus 

  • It may be present at birth or shortly thereafter.
  • They may be small or cover a large portion of the body surface.
  • Large sized (Giant )nevus > 20 cm may predispose to melanoma.
  • Often exhibit extensive nevomelanocytic infiltration of dermis with involvement of underlying adipose and muscular tissue.

The images below are - 

1 - Melanoacanthoma

2 - Malignant melanoma

3 - Epidermal verrucous nevus

questions.text: A patient has a HbA2 of 3% and HbF of 97%. A peripheral blood smear is taken. Which of the following blood pictures will be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
The presence of HbA2 3% and HbF 97% indicates that it is a case of thalassemia major. In thalassemia major, hematological findings in image 1 showing poikilocytes and image 3 showing target cells are seen. Image 2 showing Howell Jolly bodies are seen in post-splenectomy thalassemia patients and not in this case.

Hematological findings in thalassemia major include the following:

  • Anisopoikilocytosis
  • Target cells (codocytes)
  • Nucleated RBC’s
  • Dacrocytes
  • Basophilic stippling
  • Polychromatophilic cells

Related Pearl: Thalassemia syndromes

Normally each individual carries 4 functional alpha chain genes and 2 functional beta chain genes. Alpha and beta-thalassemia are inherited disorders in which there is reduced production of alpha-globin or beta-globin chains, respectively.

  • Alpha thalassemia: Gene deletion is the most common cause of reduced α-chain synthesis.
  • Beta +- thalassemia: The most common cause is splicing mutation.
  • Beta 0- thalassemia: Chain terminator mutations are the most common cause.

The table below describes the features of typical thalassemia syndromes:

Alpha thalassemias  Hb Barts HbH disease  Minor Silent carrier

Hemoglobin electro-phoresis Hb Barts (γ globin tetramers); Hb Portland (embryonic hemoglobin); no HbF, HbA, or HbA2 HbH (beta-globin tetramers -up to 30%); HbA2 (up to 4%) Hb Barts (3 to 8%) Normal

"-" denotes deletion of an alpha gene and "α" denotes normal alpha gene and "α* " refers to a mutant alpha chain gene.

Beta thalassemias Major (transfusion-dependent) Intermedia (non-transfusion-dependent) Minor (also called trait or carrier)

β0 refers to no beta-globin production; β+ refers to decreased beta-globin production.

Related Pearl: Features of Peripheral Blood Smear in Different Anemias

questions.text: A woman at 36 weeks of gestation was brought to the clinic by her concerned husband. He mentioned that over the last few weeks he noticed her chewing on cardboard pieces and ice cream sticks on multiple occasions. On examination, pallor was present and Hb was 8.6 g/dl. What is the most appropriate treatment regimen?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of pica associated with moderate iron-deficiency anemia. Since the anemia was diagnosed late in pregnancy, the most appropriate treatment is parenteral iron therapy. Ferrous sucrose is a form of parenteral iron given as an IV infusion. 

If anemia is diagnosed:

  • In the first trimester - Oral iron therapy is preferred
  • In the second trimester - Oral iron therapy should be switched over to parenteral iron if Hb falls <8g/dl or if serum ferritin is <15ng/ml
  • In the third trimester - Parenteral iron therapy is preferred

Ferrous sucrose is the most commonly used preparation for IV infusion. It is safe and does not require a test dose.

Other iron preparations include:

  • Oral preparations- Ferrous sulfate, ferrous gluconate, ferrous ascorbate 
  • IM preparations- Iron sorbitol, Iron polymaltose
  • IV preparations- Ferric carboxymaltose
  • Both IM and IV- Iron dextran.

questions.text: A patient who was on ventilator and being ventilated for past few days suddenly pulls out of the endotracheal tube. What is the next step of management?

choices.text: Watch for spontaneous breaths and reintubate if needed

questions.solution: About half of self-extubated patients may not require re-intubation. Pre-extubation FiO2, PaO2/FiO2, and ventilator mode, as well as gender, may be useful in determining the likelihood that a self-extubated patient will require re-intubation and also watch for spontaneous breathing.

questions.text: A 65 years alcoholic suffering from diabetes has a flexion deformity at right little finger over metacarpophalangeal(MCP)  joint of around 15 degree. The ideal management for him:
questions.solution:
As per the case scenario the patient is alcoholic and diabetes both risk factor of duputryen’s contracture and flexion deformity at MCP points towards the diagnosis of duputryen’s contracture.

Since the patient is elderly and flexion deformity at right little finger is 15 degree only its better left alone ie. Wait and watch.

Primary indication for surgery is fixed contracture of >30 degree  at MCP joint or >15 degree at proximal interphalangeal joint. Surgery doesn’t cure the disease it just partially corrects the deformity.

Amputation is often advisable for severe, recurrent disease in little finger.

questions.text: A 19-year-old girl presented with multiple beefy-red ulcers over the labia. Microscopic examination of smear from the lesion showed intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies and gram-negative bacteria having a safety pin appearance. What is your likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of granuloma inguinale which is caused by a gram-negative bacteria, Klebsiella granulomatis.

Granuloma inguinale begins as a painless nodule that later ulcerates to form multiple beefy red painless ulcers. These ulcers tend to coalesce and bleed easily on contact. If secondarily infected, they may become painful. The ulcers heal by fibrosis, which can result in scarring resembling keloids.

The lymph nodes are usually uninvolved but can become enlarged. New lesions can appear along the lymphatic drainage channels.

The gross image below shows granuloma inguinale of the cervix with a beefy red appearance of the hypervascular intravaginal tissues. 

The microscopic image below shows the pathognomonic intracytoplasmic Donovan bodies. It also shows clusters of gram-negative bacteria with a bipolar/safety-pin appearance.

Related Pearl: Comparison of Genital Ulcers

  Genital herpes  Syphilitic chancre (Hard chancre) Donovanosis/ granuloma inguinale Chancroid (soft chancre) LGV
Incubation period 2-7 days

10-90 days 

Average: 21days

 1-12 weeks 1-14 days 3 days - 6 weeks
Causative agent HSV-2>HSV-1 Treponema pallidum Klebsiella granulomatis Hemophilus ducreyi

Chlamydia trachomatis serovars L1,L2,L3
Clinical presentation

Cluster of vesicles on erythematous base.

Painful and pruritic lymphadenopathy

Single painless ulcer with a clean base and a firm raised border.

Painless lymphadenopathy

Painless papule or nodule erodes into beefy red granulomatous ulcer with rolled edges.

No lymphadenopathy, pseudobubos are seen

Painful ulcer (ducreyi makes you cry).

Painful inguinal lymphadenopathy

Painless genital ulcer.

Painful inguinal lymphadenopathy
Diagnosis  Tzanck preparation shows multinucleated giant cells, PCR Clinical diagnosis Donovan bodies on biopsy Clinical diagnosis Nucleic acid amplification tests
Treatment Acyclovir/famcyclovir or valacyclovir Penicillin/Ceftriaxone

Azithromycin/Doxycycline

 Azithromycin/ceftriaxone  Doxycycline

questions.text: An 18-year-old boy is rushed to the emergency department after having choked on a bone while eating. He is responsive but unable to speak. What is to be done next?
questions.solution:
In a choking child (more than 1 year old) or an adult, the first step to be done is to perform Heimlich maneuver which involves delivering abdominal thrusts.

The rescuer should stand or kneel behind the patient and wrap his arms around the patient’s waist. A fist is made with one hand and using the other hand, the fist is driven into the patient’s abdomen with a rapid, forceful upward thrust so as to dislodge the foreign body. This is continued until the foreign body is expelled or if the patient becomes unresponsive.

If the patient becomes unresponsive, immediately start CPR.

 In a choking infant who is responsive, 5 back slaps between the shoulder blades and 5 downward thrusts on the chest are given in order to dislodge the foreign body.

If the patient becomes unresponsive, immediately start CPR.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presented with the blurring of vision. Urine examination showed proteinuria. Fundus examination showed dot and blot hemorrhages, microaneurysms, and cotton wool spots. Histopathology of the kidney was as shown below. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Histopathological image shows acellular periodic acid Schiff (PAS)-positive nodules suggestive of nodular glomerulosclerosis/intercapillary glomerulosclerosis/Kimmelstiel–Wilson disease, which occurs in patients with diabetic nephropathy.

These lesions appear as ovoid or spherical, often laminated, PAS-positive nodules within the mesangial core of the glomerular lobules.

These nodular lesions are frequently accompanied by prominent accumulations of hyaline material in capillary loops (“fibrin caps”) or adherent to Bowman capsules (“capsular drops”).

Renal failure is the second common cause of death in diabetes mellitus, the first being myocardial infarction.

Three renal lesions are encountered in diabetic nephropathy:

1. Glomerular lesions:

  1. Capillary basement membrane thickening
  2. Diffuse mesangial sclerosis
  3. Nodular glomerulosclerosis/Kimmelstiel–Wilson disease

2. Renal vascular lesions, principally hyaline arteriolosclerosis

3. Pyelonephritis, including necrotizing papillitis

Renal histopathology in

  • Amyloidosis: Glomerular deposits appearing as thickenings of the mesangial matrix, forming interlacing broad ribbons of amyloid
  • Lupus nephritis: Immune complex deposits in the mesangium or along the entire basement membrane (wire loop lesions), with mesangial cell proliferation
  • Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis: Focal and segmental hyalinosis and sclerosis of the capillary wall; lipid droplets in the sclerosed area.

questions.text: A patient presents to emergency with pinpoint pupil, salivation, lacrimation, tremors and red tears. Plasma cholinesterase level was 30% of normal. Most probable diagnosis is______
questions.solution:
• Muscarinic symptoms (pinpoint pupil, salivation, lacrimation) nicotinic symptoms (tremors) points towards organophosphate levels.
  • Red tears could be due to the accumulation of porphyrin in lacrimal glands that can happen in organophosphate poisoning.
  • Organophosphates acts by inhibiting the cholinesterase enzyme activity resulting in increased acetylcholine in synapses and results in cholinergic symptoms. 
  • The decrease in cholinesterase levels below normal confirms the diagnosis of organophosphate poisoning.
  • Dhatura poisoning results in mydriasis and has almost opposite symptoms (option b).
  • Opioid poisoning and pontine hemorrhage results in pinpoint pupils but other symptoms are not characteristic of those conditions and plasma cholinesterase levels are not decreased (options b and d).

questions.text: A 20 year old girl presents with primary amenorrhea. On examination breasts were found to be poorly developed, vagina was present. Ultrasound revealed normal uterus but gonads weren’t detected. Further evaluation done showed 46XY karyotype. The most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a 46 XY individual with female internal & external genitalia and poorly developed breasts, presenting with primary amenorrhea points towards the diagnosis of sweyer’s syndrome.

Turner syndrome (option B) is a disorder of 45 XO individuals with short stature. The gonads in these individuals are streak ovaries.

Androgen Insensitivity Syndrome (option A) is a disorder of 46 XY individuals with complete insensitivity to testosterone. These individuals have female external genitalia with an absent uterus. Secondary sexual characteristics like the development of breasts are adequate. However,pubic and axillary hairs are scanty.

True hermaphrodite (option C) can be a 46 XX or 46 XY individual with both ovaries and testis. These individuals have both male and female internal genitalia with ambiguous external genitalia.

Sweyer’s syndrome is a type of male pseudohermaphroditism where there is an inactivation of the SRY gene that leads to formation of dysgenetic testis.

Thus,in the absence of hormones; AMH & testosterone the mullerian duct grows and the wolffian duct regresses forming female internal genitalia such as uterus (infantile type).

These patients also lack the DHT hormone and hence present with poorly developed breasts ( tanner staging 1 or 2), scanty pubic,axillary hair and female external genitalia. These individuals are of normal stature with increased LH & FSH.

Management includes gonadectomy as soon as diagnosed and estrogen + progesterone for breast development.

AMH: Anti mullerian hormone
DHT: dihydro testosterone

Related Pearl: Disorders of Sexual Development

Disorder

Complete androgen insensitivity

Mullerian agenesis

Turner syndrome

Complete XY dysgenesis (Swyer syndrome)

Cause

X-linked mutation of androgen receptor

Hypoplastic or absent Mullerian ductal system

Also called Mayer-Rokitansky-Küster-Hauser syndrome

Complete or partial absence of one X chromosome

SRY gene mutation on the Y chromosome

Reproductive organs

Absent uterus and upper vagina, cryptorchid testis

Absent or rudimentary uterus and upper vagina, normal ovaries

Normal uterus and vagina, streak gonads

Normal uterus and vagina, streak gonads

Breast

Yes

Yes

Variable

No

Axillary/Pubic hair

Minimal to absent

Normal

Normal

Minimal to absent

Karyotype

46 XY

46 XX

45 XO or 

45 X mosaicism

46 XY

 

Note: 

Turner's syndrome have different chromosomal anomalies:

  • 45 XO which is seen in 40-50% patients 
  • 45 X mosaicism (eg, 45,X/46,XX or 45,X/47,XXX, or 45,X mosaics with the X chromosome anomalies)

questions.text: A 70-year-old lady, a known case of chronic osteoarthritis of the hip, has a trivial fall while climbing the stairs. Her right lower limb is in slight external rotation. X-ray pelvis is shown below. What is the next step of management?
questions.solution:
The given scenario and X-ray are suggestive of right-sided fracture neck of femur, Garden stage IV. Since the patient is >65 years with existing arthritis, the best choice of treatment is total hip arthroplasty.

In the absence of arthritis, fracture neck of femur in patients >65 years, is treated by hemiarthroplasty.

The image given below shows total hip arthroplasty done for fracture neck of femur.

Related Pearl: Treatment of fracture neck of femur

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with dysphagia and Raynaud's phenomenon since the last year. Recently she has started developing skin induration in her fingers. Which of the following antibodies is likely to be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of dysphagia and Raynaud's phenomenon preceding the skin fibrosis, and the limitation of skin fibrosis to the distal extremities suggest a diagnosis of limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis. The antibody seen in this condition is anti-centromere.

Systemic sclerosis (SSc) is broadly divided into two subsets depending on the pattern of the skin involvement and other associated features:

  • Limited cutaneous (also known as CREST syndrome)
  • Diffuse cutaneous

In limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis, Raynaud's phenomenon is seen earlier and is usually more severe and can lead to critical digital ischemia. The skin lesions develop much later, sometimes years after the development of Raynaud's phenomenon. The visceral organ involvement is slowly progressive and often benign. The prominent complications include pulmonary arterial hypertension, Sjogren syndrome, and primary biliary cirrhosis. Some patients with limited cutaneous SSc develop the all characteristic set of features, known as CREST syndrome:

  • Calcinosis cutis
  • Raynaud's phenomenon
  • Esophageal dysmotility
  • Sclerodactyly
  • Telangiectasia

Related Pearl: Diffuse Cutaneous Systemic Sclerosis Versus Limited Cutaneous Systemic Sclerosis

Characteristic feature Diffuse cutaneous systemic sclerosis Limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis
Skin involvement

Rapid progression

Involvement of the skin areas proximal to the knees or elbows or over the anterior chest, trunk, or abdomen

Slow progression

Limited to face and skin distal to the elbows and knees

 

 
Raynaud’s phenomenon

Less severe

 

Short history 

More severe; commonly associated with critical limb ischemia.

Long history 
Musculoskeletal Severe arthralgia, carpal tunnel syndrome, and tendon friction rubs Mild arthralgia
Pulmonary manifestation Interstitial lung disease more common Pulmonary artery hypertension (PAH) is equal in both
Scleroderma renal crisis Occurs usually <4 years of disease onset Very rare
Calcinosis cutis Less common More common & prominent
Auto-antibodies

Anti-topoisomerase I (Scl-70)

anti-RNA polymerase III

 Anti centromere

questions.text: An 8-year-old child presents with fever and painful swelling of the left eye. He is being treated for acute ethmoiditis for 5 days. On examination, the visual acuity in the left eye is 6/12, there is chemosis, axial proptosis, limitation of ocular motility in all directions, and RAPD. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis of this patient is orbital cellulitis.

Orbital cellulitis is the most common cause of unilateral proptosis in children. Ethmoidal sinusitis is the most common cause of orbital cellulitis in children.

Orbital cellulitis presents with pain, lid edema, erythema, chemosis, and axial proptosis. Decreased ocular motility and elevated intraocular pressure can be seen. Systemic symptoms include malaise and fever. A rapid loss of vision is due to the involvement of the optic nerve. With posterior exenteration cavernous sinus thrombosis, subdural empyema, and intracranial abscess develop.

WARNING SIGNS: Dilated pupil, marked ophthalmoplegia, loss of vision, afferent pupillary defect, papilledema, and violaceous lids.

questions.text: A 5th standard girl is brought to the OPD with a high fever and cough with expectoration for 3 days. Her chest X-ray shows multiple pneumatoceles. Which of the following is the most common etiological agent implicated in this presentation?
questions.solution:
Staphylococcus aureus pneumonia manifests as confluent bronchopneumonia, which is often unilateral and characterized by the presence of hemorrhagic necrosis and irregular areas of cavitation of the lung parenchyma, resulting in pneumatoceles, empyema, or at times, bronchopulmonary fistulas. 

The following CT image shows cavitating pneumonia by S. aureus:

questions.text: A 25-year-old male prefers to be detached, does not mingle with people, and often remains alone. He does not experience pleasure and is rather preoccupied with himself and his own fantasy world. This personality type will show__________
questions.solution:
A young male who is a loner by choice and emotionally cold comes under schizoid personality. Individuals with schizoid personality have low novelty seeking.

Novelty seeking (NS) is a temperament trait in the Cloninger’s model of personality and refers to the tendency to be intensely exhilarated or excited in response to novel stimuli.

High novelty seeking:

  • Individuals high in novelty seeking are quick-tempered, curious, easily bored, impulsive, extravagant, and disorderly.
  • High novelty seeking is related to addiction, ADHD and impulsivity.
  • Cluster B personality disorders like borderline, histrionic, narcissistic and antisocial have high novelty seeking behavior.

Low novelty seeking:

  • Persons low in novelty seeking are slow tempered, uninquiring, stoical, reflective, frugal, reserved, tolerant of monotony, and orderly.
  • Individual with schizoid personality is a markedly detached person who stays alone in introspection and lives in his own world of fantasy. This is associated with having a cold attitude.

Other options:

  • Magical thinking – Schizotypal personality
  • Grandiosity - Narcissistic personality
  • Impulsivity – Borderline personality, Antisocial personality

Related Pearl: Personality Disorders

Key features of Personality disorders

Cluster A (Odd, Weird, Eccentric)
Paranoid
Suspicious, distrustful, hypervigilant
Schizoid
Prefers to be loner, detached, unemotional
Schizotypal
Eccentric & odd thoughts, perceptions & behavior, magical thinking and beliefs

Cluster B (Dramatic, Emotional and Erratic)
Antisocial
Disregard for and violation of rights of others, illegal activities
Borderline
Chaotic relationships, sensitivity to abandonment, labile mood, impulsivity, inner emptiness, self-harm
Histrionic
Dramatic, superficial, attention-seeking
Narcissistic
Grandiosity, lack of empathy

Cluster C (Anxious, Fearful, Introvert)
Avoidant
Avoidance due to fears of criticism and rejection
Dependent
Submissive, clingy, needs to be taken care of
Obsessive-compulsive/
Anankastic
 
Rigid, controlling, perfectionist

questions.text: A patient presents with fever for 1 week, with abdominal distension, loss of appetite and lymphadenopathy. There is a poor response to antibiotics and antimalarials. The Widal test is negative but  rk39 is positive. Which drug can be used in the treatment of this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient should be managed with liposomal amphotericin B.

This is a case of visceral leishmaniasis, and it presents with fever associated with rigor and chills. Splenomegaly and hepatomegaly are common. Lymphadenopathy is common in most endemic regions, but in the Indian subcontinent, it is rare. 

Diagnosis is by ELISA and the indirect immunofluorescent antibody test (IFAT) and rk39 which detects antibodies to Leishmania donovani. 

Medical Therapy :

In most endemic regions (except in India and Mediterranian countries):

  • Pentavalent antimonial is the drug of choice (sodium stibogluconate or meglumine antimoniate)
  • If initial pentavalent antimonial fails, then amphotericin B (AmB) is used.

In India and Mediterranian countries:

  • Liposomal AmB is the drug of choice.

Other drugs used in the treatment of visceral leishmaniasis include: paromomycin and miltefosine.

Other options:

Option b: Fluconazole is an antifungal and is not useful in visceral leishmaniasis

Option c: Linezolid is used in the treatment of MRSA  and related infections.

Option d: Bedaquiline is a newer anti-TB drug used in MDR-TB.

questions.text: 27-year-old female came for treatment of infertility to OPD. Bromocriptine was prescribed. What could be the possible reason?
questions.solution:
The patient is likely to be suffering from hyperprolactinemia. 

Prolactin inhibits the secretion of GnRH, which leads to the decreased secretion of LH and FSH resulting in infertility. Bromocriptine acts on Dopamine D2 receptors to reduce prolactin secretion.

questions.text:
A 55 year old chronic smoker comes with complaints of persistent cough for the past 4 months with episodes of hemoptysis and he has lost 7 kg. On examination he has normal breath sounds and temporal wasting is evident.His lab values are:
Sodium : 123 meq/L, Potassium : 4.0 mEq/L, Chloride : 96 mEq/L, Bicarbonate : 25 mEq/L, Urea : 12 mg/dL, Creatinine : 0.9 mg/dL. Which of the following is the best initial treatment?
questions.solution: This patient with the above findings likely has lung cancer. Small cell lung cancer is strongly associated with smoking and is the most common cause of SIADH due to ectopic release of antidiuretic hormone. Fluid restriction is the best initial treatment for hyponatremia due to SIADH.

questions.text: An anxious lady comes with the complaint of insomnia for 4 months. On further probing, she reveals that she eats a lot of food after her evening meals. She also wakes up in between her sleep to eat. Because of this, she has less appetite when she wakes up in the morning. She is not concerned about her appearance or about gaining weight and doesn't resort to purging activities. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of a night-eating disorder. 

The characteristics of night eating disorder include the following:

  • Recurrent episodes of hyperphagia at night (night eating)
  • The lack of desire for food in the morning
  • Insomnia

Differentiating points:

  • Although night eating can be found in bulimia nervosa and binge eating disorder, it is the characteristic sign of night eating disorder.
  • Also, the amount of food consumed during eating episodes is usually lower in night-eating disorder than in bulimia nervosa and binge-eating disorder.
  • Unlike other eating disorders, patients with night eating syndrome are not overly concerned about body image and weight.

questions.text: As a PHC medical officer, you see a 25-year-old man, who has come with painful lesions as shown below. On further probing, he tells you that he had vesicles on his penis 2 days back and that he is allergic to penicillin. On examination, he has bilateral tender lymphadenopathy. Which kit will you use to treat him?
questions.solution:
The clinical picture of multiple, grouped painful ulcers with tender lymphadenopathy in this patient points to a diagnosis of herpes genitalis infection by HSV-2. It is treated with a red kit.

The red kit or kit 5 is meant for genital ulcer disease - herpetic. It contains acyclovir 400 mg tablets to be taken TDS for 7 days.

Chancroid is a close differential diagnosis, which presents with multiple, soft painful ulcers and unilateral tender lymphadenopathy. However, vesicles are not seen in chancroid and the ulcers are deeper with ragged undermined edges.

History of drug allergy to penicillin is relevant only when the patient presents with the primary chancre of syphilis. In such a case, they would need to be treated with a blue kit instead of a white kit.

Related Pearl: Syndromic Management of Sexually Transmitted Infections

Partner Management when asymptomatic is not required for Gardenella vaginalis, Candida and Herpes infections.

questions.text: A 45 year old banker comes to the emergency department with severe back pain, vomiting and hypotension. CT was taken immediately and is given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The CT image shows Renal angiomyolipoma.

If the dilated blood vessels in an angiomyolipoma rupture, the resulting retroperitoneal bleeding causes sudden pain, accompanied by nausea and vomiting. When the patient presents in the ER, up to 20% are in shock.

Angiomyolipomas are tumors consisting of perivascular epitheloid cells. And also is composed of varying proportions of vascular, immature smooth muscle cells, and fat cells. Angiomyolipomas are typically found in the kidney, but have also been commonly found in the liver and less commonly the ovary, fallopian tube, spermatic cord, palate, and colon.

Everolimus is FDA approved for the treatment of angiomyolipomas. Treatment should be considered for asymptomatic, growing AMLs measuring larger than 3 cm in diameter. Angiomyolipomas do not normally require surgery unless life-threatening bleeding is present as in this case.

questions.text: A 35-year-old lady experiences increased frequency of urination and lower abdominal pain which is relieved by micturition. Urinalysis is normal. Cystoscopy reveals fissures and punctate hemorrhages in the bladder mucosa. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with normal urinalysis and cystoscopy findings are suggestive of interstitial cystitis.

Interstitial cystitis is a persistent, painful form of chronic cystitis, occurring most frequently in women. It is also known as chronic pelvic pain syndrome or bladder pain syndrome. Its clinical features include:

  • Severe suprapubic pain
  • Urinary frequency
  • Urgency
  • Hematuria
  • Dysuria without evidence of bacterial infection

Cystoscopic findings seen in bladder mucosa are:

  • Fissures
  • Punctate hemorrhages (glomerulations)
  • Ulcerations in the fundus of the bladder (Hunner's ulcer)

The image shows Hunner's ulcer seen in interstitial cystitis:

Treatment options include :

  • Conservative - Patient education about the chronicity of the condition, behavioral modification (timed voiding, bladder training), stress reduction, dietary alteration (avoidance of caffeine and spicy and acidic foods) and physical therapy should be the initial management for all patients.
  • Pharmacological - Neuropathic analgesics (e.g. amitriptyline, pregabalin) are used for those with a significant pain component, whereas antimuscarinics and β3-agonists are used for frequency, nocturia and urgency symptoms.
  • Surgical - For those with Hunner lesions, fulguration or laser to these lesions can be beneficial. Cystodistension as a treatment has variable evidence for success. If these options fail to improve symptoms major surgical reconstruction can be considered in selected cases.

Option b: Malakoplakia is a distinct form of inflammatory reaction seen in chronic cystitis. It appears as soft, yellow, slightly raised mucosal plaques.

Option d: Cystitis cystica occurs due to chronic irritation of the bladder mucosa. Cystoscopy reveals cystic lesions in the bladder.

questions.text: A scared mother brings her 6-year-old child to a psychiatrist. Her son wakes up at night screaming, sweating, and terrified. When she tries to console him, he does not respond. In the morning, he is unable to recall the episode. In which stage of sleep does this condition occur?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario point towards a diagnosis of night terrors (pavor nocturnus). The episodes occur during delta sleep (N3).

Night terrors are characterized by the following: 

  • Repetitive experiences of fright in which a person screams in fear during sleep (usually normal in children)
  • The person cannot be awakened
  • Autonomic disturbances may be present
  • The person has no memory of having a dream
  • Occurs during delta sleep
  • Onset in adolescence may indicate temporal lobe epilepsy

Related Pearl: Events occurring in NREM and REM sleep

Events occurring during NREM stages 3 and 4:

Events

Description

Somnambulism

Sleepwalking

Sleep terror or Night terror

Also called pavor nocturnus.

Awakens with a scream or intense anxiety. Has increased autonomic disturbances.

They do not have a memory of this when they wake up.

Runs in families and seen more frequently in childhood and boys.

Treatment with benzodiazepines is rarely required.

Nocturnal enuresis

Behavioral therapy is the mainstay.

Drugs like desmopressin and imipramine are used.

 

Events occurring in REM sleep:

Events

Description

Nightmares

Fearful sleep without autonomic disturbances that are well remembered in the morning.

TCAs may be used for treatment.

Nocturnal penile tumescence

A normal phenomenon that can be used to differentiate between psychogenic and organic impotence.

Narcolepsy

A disorder of the REM sleep characterized by disturbed sleep in the night, leading to excessive sleep in the morning.

Associated with symptoms such as cataplexy, hypnogogic and hypnopompic hallucination, and sleep paralysis.

 *Hypnogogic hallucinations are those that occur at the start of sleep and hypnopompic hallucinations are those that occur at the end of sleep.

 

Others:

Events

Description

Bruxism (teeth grinding)

Occurs in stage 2 NREM sleep.

Frontal lobe epilepsy

Occurs in stage 2 NREM sleep.

Sleep talking

Occurs in all stages of sleep and may accompany night terrors and sleepwalking.

Common in children.

No treatment is necessary.

questions.text: Following anterior dislocation of the shoulder, a patient develops weakness of flexion at elbow and lack of sensation over the lateral aspect of forearm. Which of the following nerves is injured?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of injury to musculocutaneous nerve. Musculocutaneous nerve supplies the biceps brachii and a branch of musculocutaneous nerve namely, the lateral cutaneous nerve of forearm supplies the lateral aspect of forearm. So, injury to musculocutaneous nerve results in weakness of flexion at elbow and lack of sensation over lateral aspect of forearm.

Though axillary nerve is the most common nerve damaged in shoulder dislocation, other nerves such as musculocutaneous nerve and radial nerve can also be damaged.

questions.text: An HIV patient on antiretroviral therapy presents with seizures and unilateral facial nerve palsy. The CD4 count was 150/microlitre and the MRI showed a lesion as shown below. Which among the following is the best treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and an image of MRI showing ring-enhancing lesions are suggestive of cerebral toxoplasmosis and the best treatment is the combination of sulfadiazine and pyrimethamine with leucovorin.

In HIV patients, seizures are associated with cerebral toxoplasmosis, primary CNS lymphoma, cryptococcal meningitis, and HIV encephalopathy.

Toxoplasmosis is one of the most common causes of secondary CNS infection in patients with AIDS, but its incidence is decreasing now due to combination antiretroviral therapy (ART). It is generally a late complication of HIV infection and usually occurs in patients with CD4+T cell counts less than 200/microlitre.

Fever, headache, and focal neurologic deficits are the most common clinical presentation of cerebral toxoplasmosis in patients with HIV infection. Patients present with seizure, hemiparesis, or aphasia as a manifestation of these focal deficits or accompanying cerebral edema. It is characterized by confusion, dementia, and lethargy, which can progress to coma.

The diagnosis is suspected on the basis of MRI findings of multiple lesions in multiple locations, although in some cases a single lesion is only seen. These lesions pathologically exhibit inflammation and central necrosis and, as a result, demonstrate ring enhancement on contrast MRI.

Standard treatment is sulfadiazine and pyrimethamine with leucovorin administered for a minimum of 4–6 weeks.

Other options:

Option A- Conventional amphotericin B is given through intrathecal infusion in patients with meningitis caused by Coccidioides.

Option B- Acyclovir reduces mortality and improves the neurological outcome in herpes simplex virus encephalitis.

Option C- Isoniazid (INH), rifampicin, pyrazinamide, and ethambutol are used in the treatment of tuberculous meningitis.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presented with diarrhea, bloody stools, weight loss, and intermittent fever for the past 2 months. Endoscopy revealed the following. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation along with the endoscopy image showing a cobblestone appearance are suggestive of Crohn's disease (CD).

Endoscopic findings in Crohn's disease include:

  • Aphthous ulcers - small, shallow ulcers surrounded by erythema
  • Longitudinal ulcers - linear or serpiginous deep ulcers 
  • Cobblestone appearance - deep, longitudinal ulcerations interlaced with intervening normal mucosa
  • Strictures 
  • Fistulas

Strictures and fistulae are the commonly associated complications of long-standing Crohn's disease. 

Related Pearl: Inflammatory Bowel Disease (IBD)

 

  Crohn's disease Ulcerative colitis
Age of onset  2nd-4th decades & 7th-9th decades 2nd-4th decades & 7th-9th decades 
Most common presentation Ileocolitis with rectal sparing Proctitis (rectum)
Protective factors  None 

Smoking 

Appendicectomy
Risk factors

OCP

Smoking

Antibiotic during first year of life 

α-Methyldopa

Antibiotic during first year of life
T cell involved TH1  TH2
Gross findings/ endoscopic findings

Transmural involvement

Segmental involvement

Skip lesions

Cobblestone appearance

Creeping fat

Longitudinal ulcers

Mucosal and superficial submucosal involvement 

Continuous involvement

Pseudopolyps 

Backwash ileitis 

Collar button ulcers
Earliest finding Aphthous ulcer Erythematous mucosa with a fine granular surface
Microscopic findings 

Deep, knife-like ulcers

Granulomas

Pyloric metaplasia  

Superficial, broad-based

Cryptitis and crypt abscess 

 
Complications 

Fistulas 

Strictures

Hemorrhage

Toxic megacolon
Recurrence after resection

Common

Uncommon, curative after resection
Radiological findings 

Aphthous ulcer

Rose thorn appearance

Mucosal granularity

Lead pipe appearance
Extraintestinal manifestations

Episcleritis, uveitis 

Migratory polyarthritis

Ankylosing spondylitis, sacroiliitis

Erythema nodosum

Pyoderma gangrenosum- MC in UC

Primary sclerosing cholangitis- MC in UC

Renal Calculi- MC in CD

questions.text: A mother leaves her 3-year-old son unattended for 20 mins and later finds him holding a blue coloured empty strip of tablets with a few tablets scattered on the floor. A few hours later he is rushed to the ER with nausea and vomiting.  As an intern taking the history, you suspect accidental ingestion of paracetamol tablets. The pattern of liver injury you would expect in this case is
questions.solution:
The pattern of liver injury caused by paracetamol (acetaminophen) is centrilobular necrosis.

Acetaminophen toxicity results from the formation of a highly reactive intermediate metabolite, N -acetyl-p -benzoquinone imine (NAPQI). In therapeutic use, only about 5% is metabolized by the hepatic cytochrome P450 enzyme CYP2E1 to NAPQI, which is then immediately joined with glutathione to form a nontoxic mercapturic acid conjugate.

In overdose, glutathione stores are overwhelmed, and free NAPQI is able to combine with hepatic macromolecules to produce hepatocellular necrosis. Single acute toxic dose of APAP is generally considered to be >200 mg/kg in children. 

Patterns of hepatic drug injury:

Disease  Drug 
Centrilobular necrosis  Acetaminophen, Halothane 
Microvesicular steatosis  Valproic acid 
Acute hepatitis  Isoniazid 
Fibrosis  Methotrexate 
Cholestasis  Chlorpromazine, Erythromycin, Estrogen 
Veno occlusive disease  Busulphan, Cyclophosphamide 
Portal and hepatic vein thrombosis  Estrogen, Androgen 
Biliary sludge  Ceftriaxone 
Hepatic adenoma/hepatocellular carcinoma  Oral contraceptive pills, Anabolic steroids

questions.text: A child, upon ingestion of shellfish, developed a tingling sensation in the mouth, swelling of the face, lips, and tongue, and also complained of abdominal pain and dizziness. What type of reaction is this?
questions.solution:
This child who developed tingling in the mouth, and swelling of the lips and face after eating shelf life is an example of an IgE mediated type of hypersensitivity reaction. 

Anaphylaxis is a severe, potentially life-threatening allergic reaction that occurs rapidly and affects the whole body. It is characterized by a sudden release of histamines and other chemicals from the immune system in response to an allergen, such as certain foods, medications, insect stings, or latex. The onset of symptoms can occur within minutes to a few hours after exposure to the allergen.The primary mediators are histamine and serotonin. The secondary mediators are prostaglandins and leukotrienes. 

Clinically, anaphylaxis can present with a combination of symptoms that typically include:

  • Respiratory Symptoms: Patients often experience wheezing and respiratory distress due to bronchoconstriction. Other signs may include shortness of breath, coughing, and a feeling of tightness in the chest.
  • Skin Symptoms: Urticaria (hives) and angioedema (swelling of the skin and mucous membranes) are common. These skin reactions usually develop rapidly, often within minutes to two hours of exposure to the allergen.
  • Cardiovascular Symptoms: Hypotension (low blood pressure) is a key indicator of anaphylaxis. Patients may also experience tachycardia (increased heart rate) and, in severe cases, shock.
  • Gastrointestinal Symptoms: Abdominal pain, vomiting, diarrhea, and cramps can occur, particularly if the anaphylaxis is triggered by food allergens.
  • Neurological Symptoms: Dizziness, lightheadedness, or loss of consciousness can occur due to the sudden drop in blood pressure and reduced oxygen supply to the brain.

Related Pearl: Mechanisms of Hypersensitivity Reactions

Type

Immune Mechanisms

Histopathological lesions

Immediate
 hypersensitivity
(type I)

  • Anaphylaxis
  • Allergies
  • Bronchial asthma
  • Atopic dermatitis

Production of IgE antibody →immediate release of vasoactive amines from mast cells

Vascular dilatation, edema, smooth muscle contraction, mucus production, tissue injury, inflammation

Antibody-mediated hypersensitivity
(type II)

  • Autoimmune hemolytic anemia
  • Goodpasture syndrome

Production of IgG, IgM → binds to antigen on target cell or tissue → phagocytosis or lysis of target cell by activated complement or Fc receptors; recruitment of leukocytes

Phagocytosis and lysis of cells; inflammation;

Immune complex-mediated hypersensitivity
(type III)

  • SLE
  • Serum sickness
  • Arthus reaction

Deposition of antigen-antibody complexes → complement activation →recruitment of leukocytes by complement products and Fc receptors → release of enzymes and other toxic molecules

Inflammation, necrotizing vasculitis (fibrinoid necrosis)

Cell-mediated hypersensitivity
(type IV)

  • Contact dermatitis
  • Multiple sclerosis
  • Type 1 diabetes
  • Tuberculosis

Activated T lymphocytes →

1. Release of cytokines, inflammation, and macrophage activation

2. T-cell-mediated cytotoxicity

Perivascular cellular infiltrates; edema; granuloma formation; cell destruction

questions.text: A 4-month-old male infant developed otitis media for which he was given a course of cotrimoxazole. A few days later, he developed fever, irritability, and skin tenderness followed by extensive peeling of the skin. There were no mucosal lesions. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The infant presents with an infection focus (otitis media) that is followed by generalized peeling of the skin and toxic state of the baby without any mucosal involvement which is suggestive of staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome.

  Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome Stevens-Johnson syndrome/ Toxic epidermal necrolysis
Age Infants and children under age of 6 Adults
Mucosal involvement No Yes
Nikolsky sign Positive Pseudo-Nikolsky sign Positive
Targetoid lesions Absent Present
Histopathology Acantholytic cells with subcorneal or subgranular blister

Necrotic keratinocytes

Dermo-epidermal separation

questions.text: Serologic test results from a hepatitis patient reveal: anti-HBc positive with low titres of IgM, HBsAg positive, HBe Ag negative,  and anti-HBs negative. The correct interpretation of the patient’s status is

choices.text: Hepatitis B virus chronic carrier state

questions.solution:
The serological test of this patient indicates chronic carrier state of hepatitis B.

HbsAg is positive only when the patient has acute infection or a chronic carrier and cannot be seen during window period.

Replicative activity (infectivity) is determined with level of HBeAg or HBV DNA.

Anti HbsAg is positive only during recovery or after vaccination.

Note: In contrast to the high titers of IgM-specific anti- HBc observed in acute disease, low titers of IgM anti-HBc are found in the sera of most chronic HBsAg carriers. 

Related Pearl: Interpretation of common serologic patterns in hepatitis B infection

 

 Clinical Phases HBsAg Anti-HBs HBeAg Anti-HBe Anti-HBc HBV DNA
Acute HBV - Early-phase, high infectivity

+

 - + - IgM +++

Acute HBV -Window phase

-

 - +/- +/- IgM +

Acute HBV - recovery phase

-

 + - +/- IgG +/-
Chronic HBV, high infectivity + - + - IgG +++

Chronic HBV, low infectivity

 + - - + IgG +

HBV infection in the recent past

 - + - - IgG -

HBV infection in the remote past

 - - - +/- IgG -

Post-vaccination

 - + - - - -

questions.text: A 22-year-old man was brought to the casualty with palpitations and dizziness. His heart rate was 160/min and blood pressure was 110/80 mmHg. His ECG is given below. Vagal maneuver was found to be ineffective. What would your next line of management be?
questions.solution:
The patient has paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia.

As vagal maneuver has been found ineffective, then the next best step is to administer adenosine 6 mg IV.

For treating supraventricular tachycardia, the hemodynamic status of the patient has to be assessed. In this patient, as his blood pressure is normal and there is no evidence of hemodynamic deterioration, initial treatment consists of vagal maneuvers (Valsalva maneuver) in awake patients. 

In this scenario, as this was unsuccessful, IV adenosine 6 mg had to be given. If necessary another dose of adenosine 12 mg may be administered after 1-2 minutes.

If the drug is administered via a central venous catheter, then these doses are reduced to 3 mg and 6 mg, respectively.

If there is hemodynamic deterioration, then cardioversion is the treatment of choice.

questions.text: A 72-year-old diabetic who underwent uncomplicated cataract extraction with PCIOL implant 15 days back presents with painless, decreased vision in the operated eye.  His visual acuity is 6/12 and does not improve with a pinhole. On examination, the anterior chamber is deep, and PCIOL is well-centered in the capsular bag. Dilated fundus exam reveals clear media, and optic nerve with a cup-to-disc ratio of 0.4, a few peripheral microaneurysms, and a dull foveal reflex. The rest of the fundus exam is unremarkable. Which test would be of least benefit?
questions.solution:
In the above case scenario, gonioscopy would be the least helpful.

A painless decrease in vision after cataract surgery could be due to: 

  • Posterior capsular opacification (most commonly, after 1-3 months)
  • Cystoid macular edema (early)
  • Rhegmatogenous retinal detachment (delayed)

In the given question, the media is clear (rules out posterior capsular opacification). Also, there are no symptoms nor signs of retinal detachment (RD), hence it is ruled out. Decreased vision not improving with a pinhole in the presence of clear media is attributable to macular pathology. Also, there is a dull foveal reflex. The diagnosis in this patient is cystoid macular edema (CME).

The incidence of clinical CME is about 1% to 2% following uncomplicated cataract surgeries. The incidence of angiographic evidence of CME is 10 times greater at around 10% to 20%.

Optical coherence tomography (option A) is useful in identifying cystoid macular edema and evaluating the vitreomacular interface. It is also useful in the measurement of retinal thickening, thus allowing the assessment of the therapeutic response. On fluorescein angiography (option B), the classic petaloid leakage in the fovea is seen in the case of CME. Amsler’s grid (option D) is a macular function test.

Hence, the least useful in this scenario is gonioscopy.

questions.text: A  wool farmer presents with a hemorrhagic lesion on his left index finger for 3 days. On examination, he is febrile and lymphadenopathy is present. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above image showing small, red hemorrhagic pustules with the given scenario is suggestive of orf or ecthyma contagiosum.

It is caused by the parapox virus. The commonly affected sites are hands and forearms. Lymphadenitis, lymphangitis, and fever are often present. 

It presents with a single lesion—a small, firm, red, or reddish-blue papule that develops after 5–6 days at the site of contact with an infected animal (mostly sheep and goats) and enlarges into a hemorrhagic pustule. The epidermis of an orf lesion shows ballooning degeneration of keratinocytes with eosinophilic cytoplasmic inclusions.

Treatment is usually not necessary, and the lesions heal after 3-6 weeks.

questions.text: What is the most common neurological manifestation seen in patients with systemic lupus erythematosus?
questions.solution:
The most common neurological manifestation seen in patients with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) is cognitive impairment.

It can manifest as impaired memory and reasoning. Other common neurological manifestations in SLE are psychosis, depression, and seizures.

The most common manifestations of different systems involved in SLE are:

  • Musculoskeletal- arthritis and arthralgia
  • Skin- photosensitivity
  • Kidneys- proteinuria
  • Neurologic- cognitive impairment
  • Cardiac- pericarditis
  • Pulmonary- pleuritis
  • Hematologic- anemia

questions.text: The lab report of a 35 year old lady who underwent a medical checkup suggests dyslipidemia. She has a past medical history of peptic ulcer disease. Also 2 months back, she had severe pain in her great toe which was cured temporarily by taking NSAIDs. She has been taking statins for past 1 month. Which of the below drugs is absolutely contraindicated in this patient?
questions.solution:
Niacin would be absolutely contraindicated for the lady presenting with the above clinical history. 

Contraindications to niacin are:

  • Pregnancy
  • Concurrent use with statin - causes myopathy
  • History of peptic ulcer disease
  • Gout - is a relative contraindication

Other options:

Option A- Ezetimibe in combination with statin results in further reduction of low density lipoproteins (LDL) cholesterol. However this combination should not be used in pregnant women. Ezetimibe should also not be used along with bile acid sequestrants as they inhibit its absorption.

Option B- Cholestyramine is contraindicated is severe hypertriglyceridemia (Note: since the dyslipidemia in the question is not specific, this cannot be the answer).

Option C- Evolocumab is a fully human monoclonal antibody that inhibits proprotein convertase subtilisin/Kexin type 9 (PCSK9). It is contraindicated in those with hypersensitivity.

questions.text: A patient on haloperidol complains of feeling restless and irritable with an irresistible urge to move. Which of the following drugs is used in treating this condition?
questions.solution:
The feeling of restlessness and irritability with an irresistible urge to move is called akathisia and propranolol is one of the drugs used to treat this condition.

Akathisia is an extrapyramidal side-effect of antipsychotics and usually manifests hours to days after initiating antipsychotic therapy or after an increase in dose. Treatment involves the reduction of the antipsychotic dose, administration of propranolol, benzodiazepines or drugs with anticholinergic action like benztropine or diphenhydramine.

Related Pearl: Extrapyramidal side effects of antipsychotic drugs

Adverse reactions
Time of onset
Features
Treatment
Acute dystonia
1 to 5 days
Spasm of muscles of tongue, face, neck, back
Diphenhydramine or benztropine
Akathisia
5 to 60 days
Restlessness
Propranolol, lorazepam, diphenhydramine, benztropine
Parkinsonism
5 to 30 days
Bradykinesia, rigidity, tremors
Dose reduction, change medication, antiparkinsonian agents
Tardive dyskinesia
Months to years
Orofacial dyskinesia (may be reversible with early recognition and drug discontinuation)
VMAT-2 inhibitors valbenazine and deutetrabenazine
Neuroleptic malignant syndrome
Weeks to months
Extreme rigidity, fever, unstable blood pressure
Dantrolene

questions.text: A 70 kg athlete was posted for surgery on her injured rotator cuff. She was administered a total of 640mg of succinylcholine by intermittent dosing. During recovery, she was unable to respire spontaneously and move her limbs. What is the most likely reason for this?

choices.text: Muscular weakness due to fasciculation produced by succinylcholine
Undiagnosed muscular dystrophy and muscular weakness
Phase II blockade produced by succinyl choline
Pseudocholinesterase deficiency increasing action of succinylcholine

questions.solution:
The most likely reason which led to this scenario is phase II blockade produced by succinylcholine.

Phase II block is clinically seen with the dose >5 mg/kg. It is seen with a single large dose, repeated doses, or a continuous infusion of Sch which can lead to desensitization of the receptors resulting in a prolonged neuromuscular blockade.

Causes of prolonged apnea include:

  • Atypical/pseudocholinesterase deficiency - can result in apnea even with a normal dose of succinylcholine
  • Altered response of endplate to depolarizing relaxant (myasthenia gravis)
  • Accumulation of succinylcholine leading to phase II blockade

Note: Although options A, B, and D can lead to prolonged apnea, in the above case scenario, the patient has received ~9 mg/kg of succinylcholine. Hence, the most probable diagnosis is phase II blockade leading to prolonged apnea.

questions.text: A victim of a house fire is brought to you for autopsy. On examination, you find an intracranial collection of blood. It is brown and friable and the adjacent brain tissue shows discoloration. The carboxyhemoglobin level in the extradural blood is found to be the same as in the peripheral blood. What is the likely diagnosis?

choices.text: A or C, depending on further pathological examination

questions.solution:
The diagnosis in the given scenario is that of a heat hematoma.

Heat hematoma is an artifact that mimics EDH (extradural hemorrhage). This occurs when the head has been exposed to severe external heat sufficient to burn the scalp and skull. The blood may be extruded from the diploë and venous sinuses into the extradural space to produce a heat hematoma. This false hematoma is brown and friable, and the adjacent brain tissue shows hardening and discoloration from the heat.

There is often a significant level of carboxyhemoglobin in the body if the death occurred when the fire was in progress. This should be of the same concentration in the heat hematoma as in the peripheral blood. If the victim suffered a head injury before the fire started (indicating an extradural hemorrhage), then there should be little or no carboxyhemoglobin in the hematoma.

questions.text: A 4 day old baby is active and feeding well. He has a bilirubin level of 8 mg/dl. What is the next step in the management of the baby?
questions.solution:
Since this child has a bilirubin level of only 8 mg/dl on the 4th day, it points to physiologic jaundice. The child is active and feeding well, the mother should be encouraged to continue breastfeeding frequently and exclusively.

All the other options would be possible treatment choices if the child had pathological jaundice. 

Physiological jaundice/Icterus neonatorum is due to increased bilirubin production from the breakdown of fetal red blood cells combined with transient limitation in the conjugation of bilirubin by the immature neonatal liver. It first appears on the 2nd or 3rd days usually peaks on the 4th day at 5-6 mg/dL and decreases to <2 mg/dL between the 5th and 7th days after birth.

On the other hand, in pathological jaundice, appearance is within the first 24 hours after birth and may be present at or beyond the age of 2 weeks in term babies and 3 weeks in preterms babies. There may be an elevated direct (or conjugated) bilirubin level. Jaundice visible on the palms and soles, unresponsiveness to phototherapy, and a rapid rise in bilirubin levels during phototherapy indicate pathological jaundice.

Phototherapy is initiated in babies with pathological jaundice when the bilirubin levels exceed the 95th percentile on the total serum bilirubin (TSB) normogram. Babies are kept at a distance of 30-45 cm from the UV lamp (460-490 nm) with eyes and gonads covered. It is avoided in babies with conjugated hyperbilirubinemia due to the risk of bronze-baby syndrome. Dehydration and hypocalcemia are potential complications and breastfeeding is encouraged.

Exchange transfusion (ET) is done in cases of bilirubin encephalopathy, Rh incompatibility with significant hemolysis, and bilirubin values exceeding TSB cutoffs for ET.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man presents with symptoms of low mood, fatigue, and inability to experience pleasure in any activities. He also complains of insomnia and lack of concentration. These symptoms are present during the months of winter and completely remit during spring. On further questioning, you find that he is a laborer who is always left unemployed during the winter months. What is the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Major depressive disorder with seasonal pattern

questions.solution:
Major depressive disorder is the most likely diagnosis in this case. 

DSM-V criteria for diagnosis of depression:

  1. Depressed mood most of the day
  2. Anhedonia- diminished interest in day-to-day activities
  3. Significant weight loss or weight gain and/or change in appetite.
  4. Insomnia or hypersomnia
  5. Psychomotor agitation or retardation
  6. Fatigue or loss of energy
  7. Feelings of worthlessness or excessive, inappropriate guilt
  8. Diminished ability to think or concentrate, indecisiveness
  9. Recurrent thoughts of death and suicide

At least five out of nine symptoms must be present over a two-week period and one symptom must be depressed mood or anhedonia. 

Major depressive disorder with seasonal pattern (option B) is not the diagnosis as there is the presence of a psychosocial stressor (e.g., seasonal unemployment or school schedule). It is explicitly mentioned in the question that the patient always remains unemployed during the winter months which acts as the objective psychological stressor in this case.

Major depressive disorder with seasonal pattern refers to the onset and remission of major depressive episodes at specific times of the year. In most cases, the episodes begin in the fall or winter and remit in spring. Major depressive episodes that occur in a seasonal pattern are often characterized by prominent energy, hypersomnia, overeating, weight gain, and a craving for carbohydrates. This pattern of onset and remission of episodes must have occurred during at least a 2-year period, without any nonseasonal episodes during this period. 

Dysthymia (option C) is the presence of a persistently depressed mood that lasts most of the day and is continuous. There are also feelings of guilt, irritability, and anger associated with it. These symptoms are present for at least 2 years. Dysthymia will also never present with an episode of mania/hypomania.

Cyclothymia (option D) is a mild form of bipolar II disorder, characterized by symptoms of hypomania and mild depression. Hypomania mainly includes symptoms like persistently elevated or irritable mood and abnormally increased energy lasting for at least 4 consecutive days. The depression seen in cyclothymia does not qualify the criteria for a major depressive episode.
